facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 308 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 115 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 308 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 115 of 1957.

facts.text: The appellant is a Hindu undivided family carrying on business as a dealer in iron scrap and hardware.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Hindu undivided family and carries on business as a dealer in iron scrap and hardware.

facts.text: Hoare Miller and Company Ltd. were owners of a jute pressing factory on land belonging to the Company.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs Hoare Miller and Company Ltd.--hereinafter called the Company --were owners of a jute pressing factory installed on a piece of land belonging to the Company.

facts.text: On January 21, 1941 the Company leased the jute pressing factory and machinery to Ramnath Bajoria for ten months commencing from January 10, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: On January 21, 1941 the Company leased out to one Ramnath Bajoria the jute pressing factory together with the machinery standing on the land owned by the Company for ten months companymencing from January 10, 1941.

facts.text: Ramnath Bajoria failed to vacate after lease expiry, leading to ejectment suit by the Company.

anchor.surface_text: Ramnath Bajoria failed to vacate and deliver up possession of the premises demised to him, after the expiry of the period of the lease, and the Company instituted a suit in ejectment against him.

facts.text: On October 31, 1942 the appellant agreed to purchase all rights of the Company in the factory and premises for Rs. 2,45,000.

anchor.surface_text: By an agreement dated October 31, 1942 the appellant agreed to purchase all the rights of the Company in the factory and the appurtenant premises for Rs. 2,45,000.

facts.text: On November 14, 1942 the Company delivered possession to the appellant except the leased factory part.

anchor.surface_text: On November 14, 1942 the Company delivered to the appellant possession of the property agreed to be sold, save and except the factory demised under the lease to Ramnath Bajoria and the machinery included in the lease.

facts.text: On February 26, 1943 the Company executed a conveyance in favour of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On February 26, 1943 the Company executed a companyveyance in favour of the appellant companyveying the factory and the appurtenant premises.

facts.text: On June 12, 1943 the appellant agreed to sell the property to Ranada Prasad Saha for Rs. 4,73,364/3/6 free from encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: On June 12, 1943 the appellant agreed to sell to one Ranada Prasad Saha the property purchased from the Company for Rs. 4,73,364/3/6 free from all encumbrances.

facts.text: On August 10, 1943 the appellant was substituted as plaintiff in the ejectment suit and obtained possession of the factory.

anchor.surface_text: On August 10. 1943 the appellant was substituted as a plaintiff in the suit filed by the Company against Ramnath Bajoria, and obtained possession of the factory premises.

facts.text: On September 30, 1943 the appellant conveyed the property to Ranada Prasad Saha and delivered possession.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed of companyveyance dated September 30, 1943 the appellant companyveyed to Ranada Prasad Saha the factory and the appurtenant premises and delivered possession thereof.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed Rs. 2,24,864 as profit in appellant's hands from sale to Saha.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer. District Ii 1 , CAlcutta. brought to tax in the hands of the appellant Rs. 2,24,864 bring the profit arising out of the sale of the property to Ranada Prasad Saha.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal reduced total income by Rs. 7,000.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal partially modified the order and reduced the total income by Rs. 7,000.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to Calcutta High Court on whether surplus of Rs. 2,35,211 was adventure in nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal then drew up a statement of case and referred the following question to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the surplus of Rs. 2,35,211 received by the assessee as a result of the sale of the jute press...

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Appellant never carried on business in jute or pressing jute.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was carrying on business in iron scrap and hardware and never carried on any business in jute or in pressing jute.

facts.text: At material time, appellant had closed its iron scrap business due to abnormal conditions in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: At the material time when the purchase of the Jute Press was made, the appellant had, because of abnormal companyditions prevailing in the town of Calcutta, closed its business in iron scrap and hardware.

facts.text: Appellant effected repairs to factory but made no attempt to start jute pressing business.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant purchased the jute press and the premises appurtenant thereto subject to litigation pending in the High Court, effected certain repairs and kept the factory in running companydition, but made numberattempt to start or organise the business of pressing jute...

facts.text: Appellant's plea that it could not secure labour was not true.

anchor.surface_text: ...and his plea that he was number able to secure labour for working the press was number true.

facts.text: Soon after purchase, appellant received and accepted offer from Ranada Prasad Saha to buy the factory.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after he bought the factory, the appellant received an offer from Ranada Prasad Saha to buy the factory and he immediately accepted the offer to sell it to him.

facts.text: Tribunal held the transaction was an adventure in the nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: These facts in the view of the Tribunal indicated that the appellant purchased the jute press, subject to litigation, with the sole object of reselling at profit at the earliest opportunity, and therefore the transaction was in the nature of a trading venture.

facts.text: High Court substantially agreed with Tribunal's view.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court substantially agreed with this view.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave granted by this Court, the appellant has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Capital gains were not taxable at the material time.

anchor.surface_text: At the material time, capital gains were number taxable, and the only question failing to be determined is whether profit made by the appellant by sale of the property to Ranada Prasad Saha was taxabIe under s. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appellant purchased property subject to pending litigation.

anchor.surface_text: To reiterate the sequence of material events the appellant agreed to purchase the Jute Press from the Company on October 31, 1942 subject to litigation pending in the High Court of Calcutta...

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Tribunal and High Court erred in holding rights in Sch. II and III lands not sold to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court were, in our judgment, in error in holding that the right of the Company was number sold to the appellant in the lands in Sch. II and Sch. III properties.

facts.text: Appellant did not organize jute pressing business, obtain licence, secure orders or employ labourers.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the appellant had put the factory in a working companydition, but had number organized a jute pressing business, had number obtained a licence for working the factory, had number attempted to secure orders for pressing jute, and had number employed labourers...

facts.text: Appellant's claim of inability to secure labourers not accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claim that it was number s9 done because the appellant companyld number secure labourers has number been accepted.

facts.text: Agreement to sell to Saha executed before obtaining possession on Aug 10, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: But before the 10th of August an agreement of sale was executed by the appellant in favour of Ranada Prasad Saha.

facts.text: Supreme Court infers no intention to commence jute pressing business.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the sequence of events, the inference that the appellant had numberintention to companymence doing jute pressing business does number necessarily follow.

facts.text: No evidence of sole intention to resell at profit.

anchor.surface_text: Even if that inference be regarded as binding upon the Court it cannot be presumed that the sole intention of the appellant was to start a venture in the nature of trade.

facts.text: Supreme Court discharges High Court's affirmative answer and records negative answer.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore discharge the answer given by the High Court in respect of the question submitted by the Tribunal and record a negative answer. The appeal is allowed.

facts.text: Appeal allowed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 115 of 1957.
With special leave granted by this Court, the appellant has appealed to this Court.

At the material time, capital gains were number taxable, and the only question failing to be determined is whether profit made by the appellant by sale of the property to Ranada Prasad Saha was taxabIe under s. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show isolated purchase and resale of immovable property unrelated to assessee's business; no subdivision, processing or trade indicia; profit expectation alone insufficient; lower courts erred on property rights conveyed; burden on revenue not discharged

holdings.text: Profit made by the appellant by sale of the property to Ranada Prasad Saha was not taxable under s. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: At the material time, capital gains were not taxable, and the only question failing to be determined is whether profit made by the appellant by sale of the property to Ranada Prasad Saha was taxable under s. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

holdings.text: The facts do not make out the case that the transaction was an adventure in the nature of trade

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of criteria from precedents to facts: isolated, unrelated to business, no alteration/treatment, no advertising/brokers, property type suitable for letting not trading commodity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recitals in conveyance deeds indicate full rights transferred without reservation

anchor.surface_text: It has consistently been held by this Court that the question whether profit in a transaction has arisen out of an adventure in the nature of trade is a mixed question of law and fact

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent precedent; permits review under s.66(1)

holdings.text: It is for the revenue to establish that the profit earned in a transaction is within the taxing provision and is on that account liable to be taxed as income

anchor.surface_text: It is for the revenue to establish that the profit earned in a transaction is within the taxing provision and is on that account liable to be taxed as income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature determined from all facts and circumstances on record

holdings.text: A profit motive in entering a transaction is not decisive, for, an accretion to capital does not become taxable income, merely because an asset was acquired in the expectation that it may be sold at profit

anchor.surface_text: It may be emphasized from an analysis of these cases that a profit motive in entering a transaction is not decisive, for, an accretion to capital does not become taxable income, merely because an asset was acquired in the expectation that it may be sold at profit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analysis of precedents distinguishes trade indicia from mere profit expectation

holdings.text: Even if the appellant had no intention to commence doing jute pressing business it cannot be presumed that the sole intention of the appellant was to start a venture in the nature of trade

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the sequence of events, the inference that the appellant had no intention to commence doing jute pressing business does not necessarily follow. holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of business organization not conclusive of trade intent; no other evidence of trading purpose
